investigation.title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells.
investigation.description: Natural killer (NK) cells are an important first-line of defense against malignant cells. Because of the potential for increased cancer risk from astronaut exposure to space radiation, we determined whether microgravity present during spaceflight affects the body's defenses against leukemogenesis.

project.funding: This work was supported by Grant NNX17AE49G from NASA Space Biology and by the NASA Translational Research Institute for Space Health (TRISH) through Cooperative Agreement NNX16AO69A. B.M.K. and J.H.D. are supported by T32 pre-doctoral fellow positions through NIH NIBIB 2T32EB014836.

publications.title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells.
publications.summary: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells. — 10.1038/s41526-024-00424-1

parameters.Growth Medium: NK MACS® Medium (Miltenyi Biotech, Auburn, CA, USA), supplemented with 5% Human AB Serum (Corning Life Sciences, Durham, NC, USA) and 500 IU/mL Human Recombinant IL-2 (StemCell Technologies, Vancouver, Canada)
parameters.Cell Isolation Kit: human NK Cell Isolation Kit (MACS - Miltenyi Biotec)
parameters.Culture Vessel: Synthecon’s Rotating Cell Culture System (RCCS) in conjunction with High Aspect Ratio Vessels (HARVs)
